Award.AwardTitle: Early Career: Acquisition of a laser ablation system to enable new constraints on continental crust, dinosaurs, and ore deposits
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to use laser ablation techniques to understand three fundamental aspects of the Earth system: 1) the origin and evolution of Earth?s continents, 2) the preservation of fossil bone material and its use in constraining aspects of Earth?s paleoclimate, and 3) understanding the source and development of economic ore deposits. Of particular interest to the national interest is the project?s efforts to mitigate dinosaur fossil bone poaching and to develop new methods for understanding the origin of economically viable metal ore deposits. This award also provides critical analytical support for three early career scientists, including two women, one of whom is Hispanic. Finally, the award will help establish a new laboratory that will facilitate the education of undergraduate and graduate Earth scientists in cutting edge analytical techniques that are applicable to understanding the Earth environment.

This award will help establish the University of Arkansas? TRAIL facility (Trace element and Radiogenic Isotope Laboratory). Laser ablation capabilities provided by this award will be used to develop both conventional and split-stream analytical protocols for accessory phases, fossil bone, and sulfides utilizing the laboratory?s existing multi-collector and quadrupole ICP-MS instruments. The lab will be focused on three main goals: 1) using accessory phase (e.g., monazite, zircon, and titanite) Th-U-Pb petrochronology to constrain the metamorphic reactions that occur during melting and deformation in the deep continental crust, 2) understanding vertebrate taphonomy and its utility for constraining aspects of paleoclimate and paleoecology, and 3) providing new constraints on the genesis of economic ore deposits via the in situ analysis of Pb-isotopes, Cu-isotopes, and trace elements in sulfides. A fourth early career scientist in the Department of Anthropology will utilize LA-ICP-MS to analyze archeological pottery to constrain trade networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded a new laser ablation system for research conducted by three early career Earth scientists at the University of Arkansas. The grant also provided 3 years of salary support for a new research scientist who serves as the manager for the TRAIL facility (Trace element and Radiogenic Isotope Laboratory). The 4-year old facility has enabled a wide variety of applications using both in situ laser ablation and solution-based inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry. The facility has grown into a multi-disciplinary lab, impacting scientists, students, and external users in Earth science, economic geology, hydrology, chemistry, engineering, archaeology, and agriculture.

Intellectual Merit. The new facility developed a number of laser ablation protocols using its existing quadrupole ICP-MS for internal and external users. These included (1) U-Pb detrital zircon geochronology, (2) high resolution compositional mapping of garnet, sulfides, feldspar, and other phases, and (3) trace element analysis of silicates, oxides, phosphates, sulfides, fossil bone, and pottery. Detrital zircon analysis led to new constraints on provenance of paleo-rivers in North America, and the University of Arkansas now hosts the Detrital Geochronology Laboratory – an industry consortium in the Department of Geosciences. Current research on trace element zoning in garnet is providing new constraints on the evolution of Earth’s lower continental crust, including the impact of mafic underplating and garnet residue production during high pressure melting of sedimentary protoliths emplaced into the lower crust. In situ analysis of sulfides in both magmatic-hydrothermal and hydrothermal ore deposits are leading to new constraints on the formation of economic ore deposits. The facility has also analyzed archaeological pottery to help anthropologists constrain trade networks of past Native American cultures.

Broader Impacts. Since its beginning in 2016, TRAIL and the laser ablation facility, the teaching and educational impact of this laboratory has been significant (as of August 2020), with 113 student users to date: 64 undergraduates, 38 graduates, and 11 postgraduate fellows. The research impact of TRAIL is evidenced by 115 conference presentations and 78 peer-reviewed publications in that same time period. 33 student theses were completed with TRAIL-acquired data. The facility now impacts several colleges campus-wide, including: Arts & Sciences, Engineering, and Agriculture. 23 faculty and students from outside the University of Arkansas have also used the TRAIL facility. Importantly, TRAIL’s research scientist, initially funded by the National Science Foundation via this grant, is now a full-time employee of the University of Arkansas, thus ensuring the long-term success of TRAIL.
